meta.title: COVID 19 - Center School District

body.class: fsLiveMode fsHasHeader fsHasFooter fsHasOneColumnLayout fsSection803 fsHasTheme10

input.name: q
input.title: search
input.style: width: 100%; padding: 0px; border: none; margin: -0.0625em 0px 0px; height: 1.25em; outline: none;

div.p: Dear Center School District Families,
Let me start by extending my sincere appreciation to the Center School District community for your incredible support as we have navigated through this unprecedented situation the past several weeks.

While I wish I was sharing more promising news about the students and staff returning to school to complete the 2019-2020 school year, Governor Mike Parson has announced the closure of schools for the remainder of the school year which concludes May 22, 2020.

I know how hard it has been for our country, our community and our families to change the way we live to stop the spread of COVID-19. The announcement that we will not return for the remainder of this year may be difficult to process, but please remember we are all in this together. While the academic plans we have put in place are not a replacement for traditional classroom instruction, out staff is committed to providing educational opportunities for students throughout this closure. With your partnership, we will conquer even the most challenging times.

We appreciate the collaborative spirit demonstrated over the past several weeks. It has been heart-warming to see our community come together to care for one another. We will continue to provide updates in the weeks to come. Thank you for your continued support of the Center School District.
Michael Weishaar, Ph.D.
Interim Superintendent, Center School District
Dear Center School District Community,

Mayor Lucas issued a “stay at home” order for any person not performing essential services starting Tuesday, March 24. He has also closed schools through Friday, April 24 to help stop the spread of COVID-19. This includes the Center School District. As communicated earlier, we will still deliver meals starting on Monday. We ask that anyone who has been recommended to self-quarantine to use precaution and help keep our Center Community healthy.
With these new developments, we ask only parents and guardians who cannot re-fill necessary student medications to access the front offices on Monday from 10:00-2:00.

You will receive additional communication from building principals/teachers detailing instructional plans for first two weeks of closure. We are working towards our “Phase Two” of instructional plans with a target start date of April 6. Expectations for both students and staff will increase so that we can keep students connected to learning. Building leaders will also send further instructions regarding potential device distribution and internet access.
We understand the new circumstances are not easy for any of us to process, but we must do our part in stopping the spread of the Coronavirus.
Below is a joint message from the Cooperating Schools of Greater Kansas City.
Thank you for your understanding and cooperation,
Michael Weishaar, Ph.D.
Interim Superintendent, Center School District

SCHOOLS ACROSS THE KANSAS CITY REGION
TO REMAIN CLOSED THROUGH APRIL 24
Kansas City, Mo. (March 21, 2020) — School districts across the Kansas City region agreed to keep schools closed in our area through April 24, after a group call with Kansas City Mayor Quinton Lucas.

The mayor also let schools know his new stay-at-home order would have exceptions to allow school district employees to continue the important work they are doing to feed children and provide academic opportunities.

“Our superintendents expressed their thanks to Mayor Lucas for his leadership in this coordinated, regional response,” said Kenny Southwick, executive director of the Cooperating Schools of Greater Kansas City.
Each district will communicate individually with its community to let students, staff and families know what this means to them.

Our goal is to ensure students are connected to learning to the greatest extent possible. Our staff has been working together to develop online and off-screen learning to focus on key concepts, knowledge and skills through essential learning standards. If you have questions about the content available online or in the learning packets, please feel free to contact your child’s classroom teacher by email.
You may also use this guide to help you learn more about the virtual learning applications: Parent Technology Tutorials

4th -12th grade will be provided work online as devices have been distributed to students in those grade levels. Please login to your Google Classroom for lessons. If you are having difficulty logging in, please reach out to your teacher(s).

ul.li: Lessons will be posted for students in their Google classroom.
As student work is completed, teachers will provide feedback and note missing assignments.
Teachers and principals will be available to answer questions related to learning and will respond to students by email.

Students who receive special education services will continue to be contacted by their IEP case managers to outline any individualized learning necessary, based on the IEP, and provide assistance as needed.

District technology support for devices issued will be available from 7:00 am. to 5:00 pm. Monday through Friday, Tuesday and Thursday from 5:00 pm.– 9:00 am. Calls will be answered at (816) 349-3304. You can also submit an online ticket at https://v.gd/CSDsupport
Early Childhood Teachers and families will continue their regular interactions using Seesaw.
The Early Childhood packet has learning and enrichment opportunities beginning April 8 and running through April 24.
When you review the packet, you will find that the days are labeled, Day One, Day Two and so on.

Packets will be available for pick up at the already established meal distribution sites, Monday, April 6 and Tuesday, April 7. For locations and times visit: under the meals tab: https://www.center.k12.mo.us/covid-19

div.p: Due to the rare challenges this pandemic has caused, student work for the remainder of this school year will not be traditionally graded. While we cannot require work to be completed, we recommend all work be completed and submitted so feedback can be provided.

· K-5th grades: On-going feedback will be provided as work is returned. 4th quarter progress reports will be reported based on students’ acquisition of essential standards (“Meets Expectations” or “Progressing Towards Expectations”).
· ​6th-12th grades: 3rd quarter grades will serve as current semester grades. However, students will have the opportunity to raise their grades in the following ways:

o Students may work with teachers to complete missing assignments and/or improve upon any work that has already been submitted from 3rd quarter. Individual assignments/projects/assessments completed at a higher percentage will replace the lower grade.

o Virtual assignments completed from new 4th quarter work will be counted in the student’s grade ​average only if it improves their overall semester cumulative grade. If ​completed and scored assignments do not improve the semester cumulative grade, students ​should partner with their classroom teachers ​for guidance on how to correct that work until improvement is made.

We understand there may be students who do not have access to personal devices and/or internet service. In these cases, the learning opportunities may also be accessed on mobile devices and completed on paper. We will provide opportunities to complete unfinished work, as appropriate, when students return.
Comcast and Charter are offering free internet service to some qualifying families. Click the following links if you would like additional information.

The district technology support will be available from 7:00 am to 5:00 pm Monday through Friday. Tuesday and Thursday evenings will also be staffed to take calls from 5:00 pm – 9:00 pm. Calls will be answered at (816) 349-3304. You can also submit an online ticket at https://v.gd/CSDsupport At this time we are not providing physical device support.
You may also use this guide to help you learn more about the virtual learning applications: Parent Technology Tutorials

Families of 4th - 8th graders, who completed the survey requesting a Chromebook, will have one more opportunity to pick up their device at Center Middle School located at 326 E. 103 rd. Street on Wednesday, April 8 from 11:00 am. – 1:00 pm.

We previously asked families to drive through Center Middle School on Wednesday, April 1- Friday, April 3 to pick up the devices. We asked families to stay in their vehicle during the distribution process which would occur in front of the building. Families who did not initially request a device would not have one available during the initial pick-up times. Please contact your teacher/principal to request a device and another pick-up time will be arranged.
· Students with last names that start with letters A-H - 11:00 am – 2:00 pm on Wednesday, April 1
· Students with last names that start with letters I-O - 11:00 am – 2:00 pm on Thursday, April 2
· Students with last names that start with letters P-Z - 11:00 am – 2:00 pm on Friday, April 3

We encourage you to adhere to the guidelines and recommendations put in place by our local, state, and national government agencies. We want to contain the number of families to help limit the spread of COVID-19 in our community.

We are pleased to announce a partnership with Sodexo and Student Transportation of America in preparing and delivering meals to all Center School District students. If you have questions, you may call 816.349.3300 M-F 8:00 – 4:00.
In an effort to minimize the risk of spreading COVID-19, We have altered our delivery schedule.

p.b: Starting Monday, April 13, sack meals will be available at our four elementary schools from 11:00 a.m. – 11:30 a.m. on Monday, Wednesday and Friday. We will no longer provide meals at selected bus stops.

ul.li: Each student may pick up four meals (two breakfasts/two lunches) on Monday and Wednesday and two meals (one breakfast/one lunch) on Friday.

Elementary School Addresses: Center Elementary: 8401 Euclid Kansas City, MO 64132, Boone Elementary: 8817 Wornall Road, Kansas City, MO 64114, Indian Creek Elementary: 9801 Grand Kansas City, MO 64114, Red Bridge Elementary: 10781 Oak, Kansas City, MO 64114
Students no longer need to be present to receive a meal; parents/guardians may pick up meals for their child(ren).
All children under the age of 18 are eligible to receive the free meals.
We also ask that you follow all health recommendations and practice social distancing.

div.p: Additional food resouces within 5 miles of Center School District. (PDF)

If you need access to your child’s medication, each building will be open on Monday, March 23 from 10:00 a.m. - 2:00 p.m. for you to pick up. Please understand this is for medicine only and we cannot allow access to the rest of the building. Medications will only be released to parents/guardians and proper identification will be required.

After this date, you will not be able to access your child’s medication and/or medical equipment until school resumes. If you have questions, please email Meagan Patterson, Director of Special Services, at mpatterson@center.k12.mo.us.

Starting Monday, March 23, you may call (816) 349-3300 Monday-Friday from 8:00 a.m. - 4:00 p.m. with questions. We ask that you remain flexible and check your email on a regular basis for updates as this will be our primary form of communication.
Contact information for each school is listed below.

ul.li: Early Childhood Center PDF
Boone Elementary PDF
Center Elementary PDF
Indian Creek Elementary PDF
Red Bridge Elementary PDF
Center Middle School PDF
Center Alternative School PDF
Center High School PDF

li.a: Summer School/ End of Year Events

h2.a: Summer School/ End of Year Events

div.p: Summer School is currently scheduled for June 1-25. With the decision to keep buildings closed for the remainder of the year, we will continue to monitor public health concerns to assess how our plans may be impacted. Also, Center School District looks forward to celebrating Graduation with the Class of 2020 and other end of the year events when we are confident they can be completed safely.

Students visiting countries under level 3 travel advisories with the CDC (currently China, Italy, South Korea, and Iran) from now through the end of the school year will be asked to stay home from school for 14 days upon their return to the country. During these 14 days, students will not be penalized and will be eligible to receive make-up schoolwork. This also applies to staff members traveling abroad. If your student is traveling to any of the countries mentioned above this semester, please inform your school administrator. Together you will work on a plan to gather make-up work. It is important to note that during these 14 days, students also may not participate in any school activities, programs, clubs, etc.

We do want to provide a little more information regarding precautionary measures the District is implementing in partnership with the Missouri and Kansas City Health Department as well as the Center for Disease Control (CDC). The CDC recommends the District adhere to the following guidelines:
· The District will continue to communicate closely with county and city health professionals.
· District nurses will monitor student illnesses and review CDC and state health department guidelines.

· The District will continue to use both routine cleaning methods and specialized decontamination equipment to provide extra disinfection efforts in classrooms and school buildings that have reported an uptick in illnesses.
· The District is evaluating its current crisis and emergency procedures related to health and illness in collaboration with health department and law enforcement partners.
· Health Services staff members will attend training sessions regarding the possibility of a pandemic flu virus.

· The District will reinforce best practices to prevent the spread of flu, influenza and other viruses to staff and students. The number one way to stop the spread of illness remains to stay home if you are displaying any symptoms.

There is no vaccine for the coronavirus, and the best way to prevent the infection is to avoid exposure. The incubation period (the time between exposure and symptoms) is between one and 14 days. As a public school district, we play an important role in slowing the spread of COVID-19 by helping to ensure students and staff have safe and healthy learning environments. Respiratory viruses are transmitted from person to person when an infected person coughs or sneezes, or when a person touches something that has the flu virus on it and then touches his or her mouth, eyes or nose. While most of the population is at a greater risk of contracting seasonal influenza than coronavirus, it is essential that we partner to prevent the spread of all illnesses by embracing the following practices:

ul.li: Students visiting countries under level 3 travel advisories with the CDC (currently China, Italy, South Korea, and Iran) from now through the end of the school year will be asked to stay home from school for 14 days upon their return to the country. During these 14 days, students will not be penalized and will be eligible to receive make-up schoolwork. This also applies to staff members traveling abroad. If your student is traveling to any of the countries mentioned above this semester, please inform your school administrator. Together you will work on a plan to gather make-up work. It is important to note that during these 14 days, students also may not participate in any school activities, programs, clubs, etc.

Staying home if you are sick with the flu or are presenting symptoms of the flu to prevent spreading it to others at school and in the workplace. If you believe you or your children are becoming ill with influenza-like symptoms (such as fever, cough, sore throat, body aches, headache, chills and fatigue), contact your local healthcare provider.
Avoiding touching your mouth, nose and eyes because the virus can spread when your hands touch surfaces infested with germs.
Practicing frequent hand washing using soap and warm water for at least 20 seconds. You may also use hand sanitizer when it is difficult to wash your hands.
Practicing “social distancing,” especially in the case of a pandemic. Stand at least three feet away from others if you or the other person is infected with the flu.
Not sharing drinks, water bottles, eating utensils or cell phones with others.

Remembering to cover your mouth and nose with a tissue when coughing and sneezing. If a tissue is not available, sneezing or coughing into the upper portion of your shirt sleeve and avoid sneezing or coughing into your hands (which are more likely to touch surfaces and other people and spread the disease).
Ensuring that children and adults are fever-free for 24 hours without medication before returning to work or school.

If possible, getting a flu shot. How do you tell the difference between the common cold and the flu? If you have a stuffy nose, sneezing, sore throat and a hacking cough, you probably have a cold. If you have a high fever, extreme tiredness, a dry cough and severe headache, muscle and body aches, you probably have the flu.

National Association of School Psychologists has partners with the National Association of School Nurses to provide talking points to help parents talk to children about COVID 19. Visit www.nasponline to learn more specific guidelines.

Our mental health tool kit is full of resources to help navigate these unprecedented and challenging times. Resource include: Coronavirus specific resources and apps, meditation videos, relaxing music, sounds of nature, interactive stress relief, general mental health resources, podcast and blogs. As more resources become available, updates will be made.

div.p: More Resources

ul.li: Food Resources within 5 miles of Center School District

li.a: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Missouri Department of Health and Senior Services

div.p: You may click the respective links to find additional information on coronavirus.

District staff take health concerns seriously and will be monitoring illness in schools, and that we will share additional information or guidance we receive from county, state and federal health professionals.
If we all work together and follow these important guidelines, we can keep our students, staff, and community healthy.

ul.li: Center School District
8701 Holmes Road
Kansas City, MO 64131
